scientific_summary: Anticipation can fuel motivation when channelled through planning, mindfulness, and reality-based preparation (Carver & Scheier, 1998).

immediate.title: Body readiness scan
instructions: Stand or sit tall and breathe in for four counts, out for six.
Scan from head to toe, noting areas of tension or eagerness.
On each exhale, soften the tight spots to balance excitement with steadiness.

evidence.summary: Somatic awareness helps modulate arousal and supports balanced anticipation.

immediate.title: Clarity question
instructions: Ask yourself: 'What am I most looking forward to, and why does it matter?'.
Write a single sentence capturing the opportunity ahead.
Repeat the sentence as a grounding affirmation.

evidence.source: Carver & Scheier, On the Self-Regulation of Behavior, 1998
evidence.summary: Clarifying motives aligns anticipatory energy with goal pursuit.

immediate.title: Vagal reset sip
instructions: Take a slow sip of cool water while exhaling for six counts.
After swallowing, hum softly for 10 seconds to stimulate the vagus nerve.
Repeat twice while dropping your shoulders with each exhale.

evidence.summary: Brief vagal toning exercises modulate anticipatory arousal and support social engagement.

short_term.title: If-then planning
instructions: Identify one desired outcome and one potential obstacle.
Create an if-then plan (e.g., 'If I feel overwhelm before presenting, then I will do 4-4-6 breathing').
Write the plan on a card or phone note to revisit before the event.

evidence.summary: Implementation intentions improve goal attainment by pre-deciding responses.

short_term.title: Process visualization
instructions: Close your eyes and imagine yourself moving through the upcoming event step by step.
Focus on process actions (breathing, speaking, posture) rather than outcome.
End by picturing the post-event reflection and one lesson learned.

evidence.source: Taylor & Pham, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 1998
evidence.summary: Process-focused visualization improves performance and manages anticipatory stress.

short_term.title: Focus interval rehearsal
instructions: Break the upcoming event into 3 timed intervals (opening, middle, close).
For each interval, jot the key objective and one grounding cue (breath, keyword).
Practice walking through the intervals aloud or with a supportive peer.

evidence.source: Moran, International Review of Sport and Exercise Psychology, 2016
evidence.summary: Segmented mental rehearsal improves performance under anticipatory stress.

long_term.title: Progress journal
instructions: Each week, record one event you anticipated and note what went well, what was challenging, and what you learned.
Highlight one strength you used during the experience.
Identify a micro-adjustment for the next anticipated event.

evidence.summary: Reflective journaling enhances growth mindsets and adaptive anticipation.

long_term.title: Strength-building practice
instructions: Choose one skill that supports your anticipated goals (e.g., presentation, empathy).
Schedule a practice session or training every two weeks.
After each practice, log one takeaway and how it lowers future anxiety.

evidence.summary: Skill rehearsal increases self-efficacy, channeling anticipatory arousal into confidence.

long_term.title: Monthly implementation review
instructions: List anticipated events from the past month and rate preparation confidence vs. outcome.
Note which preparation behaviors correlated with calmer performance.
Select one behavior to amplify for next month and schedule it on the calendar.

evidence.source: Duckworth et al., Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 2011
evidence.summary: Regular implementation reviews strengthen grit and effective anticipation strategies.

friend_support.title: Co-create a celebration plan
instructions: Ask your friend what outcome they hope to savor after the event.
Design a small celebratory ritual you can share (voice memo, walk, favorite snack).
Schedule the ritual on both calendars to reinforce motivation and reduce performance pressure.

evidence.source: Roepke et al., Journal of Positive Psychology, 2018
evidence.summary: Planning shared savoring experiences increases anticipatory joy and buffers stress.

friend_support.title: Reality-check conversation
instructions: Invite your friend to list their top two hopes and two realistic constraints.
Reflect back balanced statements that honor both excitement and limits.
Agree on one practical step they can take this week to feel prepared.

evidence.source: Nadeau et al., Cognitive Therapy and Research, 2019
evidence.summary: Supportive cognitive reframing with peers reduces anticipatory anxiety and improves planning accuracy.

self_repair.title: Repair when I overpromised
instructions: State the commitment you made in anticipation ("I said I'd deliver by Monday").
Explain the updated realistic timeline and what you are doing to meet it.
Offer a make-good option (partial draft, progress update) and invite feedback.

evidence.source: Lewicki & Polin, Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes, 2013
evidence.summary: Transparent renegotiation with a concrete plan rebuilds trust after unmet expectations.

self_repair.title: Contain my anticipatory anxiety
instructions: Write how your own anxious anticipation affected the other person (e.g., constant checking in).
Identify one boundary you can set for yourself (scheduled updates instead of frequent messages).
Share the boundary and ask what would help them feel supported while you prepare.

evidence.summary: Meta-communication about anxiety maintains relationship satisfaction during high-stakes preparation.
